keyTakeAways: The Ostwall, a massive Nazi underground complex in Poland, was abandoned after WWII and is now a dark tourism destination.

The London Tunnels, built during WWII for civil defense and later used by British spies, are undergoing a $149 million renovation to become a major tourist attraction.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article explores several underground historical sites around the world, highlighting their transformation from military or historical uses into tourist attractions. It centers on Poland’s Ostwall — a 20-mile Nazi-built underground complex abandoned in 1945 — now a dark tourism destination managed by the Międzyrzecz Fortified Region Museum. The article also covers the Roman Passage of Commodus, where Emperor Commodus allegedly survived an assassination attempt, now set to open to the public. In London, a mile-long WWII-era tunnel used by the Special Operations Executive is being renovated into a major tourist site, inspired by James Bond. In Turkey, the abandoned ghost town of Kayaköy and ancient Babylon in Iraq are presented as haunting remnants of history. The West Virginia asylum, once a place of compassion, is now a macabre tourist attraction with paranormal elements. Together, these stories illustrate how dark, historical, and forgotten underground spaces are being repurposed for public engagement and tourism.
title: Deep underground, the Nazis built a city for thousands of soldiers. Now it’s a tourist attraction
